{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3547130,"name":"","username":"star_E","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/898d66/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-04T14:17:03.869Z","cooked":"

I’m curious as to whether I should take the time to research and implement a Kalman Filter into my Vision subsystem. I’ve heard good things about them, but I’m curious as to whether someone has actually used one in a robot for FRC and whether it makes a difference compared to just averaging the pose estimations from my 4 cameras, which is what I have set up currently. Thanks!

Somebody will likely be quick behind me with a better explanation.

But the wpilib poseEstimator has a Kalman filter when addvisionmeasurement() is run and you can configure custom standard deviations for conditions like distance, angular velocity, or whatever you feel the need to filter out bad readings.

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

Pose Estimators

WPILib includes pose estimators for differential, swerve and mecanum drivetrains. These estimators are designed to be drop-in replacements for the existing odometry classes that also support fusing...

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2025-03-04T14:41:46.556Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":305,"readers_count":304,"score":76.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":494180,"topic_slug":"is-a-kalman-filter-a-viable-way-to-get-an-accurate-pose-estimation","display_username":"Eric (319)","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://docs.wpilib.org/en/stable/docs/software/advanced-controls/state-space/state-space-pose-estimators.html","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Pose Estimators — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation","clicks":22}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":23786,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Awaiting our Robot Overlords since 2013"},"post_url":"/t/is-a-kalman-filter-a-viable-way-to-get-an-accurate-pose-estimation/494180/2","custom_user_title":"Awaiting our Robot Overlords since 2013","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3547389,"name":"","username":"ThatChair","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/thatchair/{size}/199567_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-04T18:11:52.075Z","cooked":"

We use an ExtendedKalmanFilter setup, and it was miles better than what we previously used, which was essentially a weighted average. I have heard good things about wpilib’s poseEstimator, but we wanted to create our own for flexibility. If you want to make your own, I would look at 1678’s code, just be aware it could take time to debug and get working.

On a side note, making sure you are feeding good data into whatever you are using is essential. The right standard deviation can make all the difference, and make sure your robot to camera transforms are spot on.

i’m curious how this works for you. what’s better about it?

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2025-03-04T19:06:12.724Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":185,"readers_count":184,"score":42.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":494180,"topic_slug":"is-a-kalman-filter-a-viable-way-to-get-an-accurate-pose-estimation","display_username":"joel truher","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":60372,"username":"ThatChair","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/thatchair/{size}/199567_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53190,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/is-a-kalman-filter-a-viable-way-to-get-an-accurate-pose-estimation/494180/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3547604,"name":"","username":"ThatChair","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/thatchair/{size}/199567_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-04T21:50:20.347Z","cooked":"

Better than what? Our previous method was very basic, and functioned as a weighted average. We tried something that simple as it was comparatively easy to understand and pass on to new students. For your information, the exact formula was E = \frac{\sum\limits_{i=0}^{n} (s_i^{-2} m)}{\sum\limits_{i=0}^{n} (s_i^{-2})}, where E was the estimate, s was standard deviation of the measurement, n is the number of measurements, and m was the measurement. After localization inaccuracy last year, we overhauled the whole system, including upgrading to a kalman filter. I haven’t done an actual analysis on which is better, but empirically the kalman filter seemed to have less jitter.

If you meant better than the PoseEstimator, I assume it’s probably similar, but our solution allows us to easily use our custom odometry or even fuse questnav data if we so choose.

EDIT: For some reason the formula isn’t rendering for me.

that is what it should look like.

We do the exact same - and this is what I would suggest for it’s simplicity. You will get good results, and it’s pretty easy to understand and debug.

It allows use to compute custom stddevs for our odometry - so we can increase the stddevs when we detect a collision or skidding
